comment.body: Well, GFW seems to be empty, and Bitcoin only has two people registered with a grand total of 2 posts, 1 like, and 1 follow of nofish. Haven't checked the others yet.
What did you change?
LOL, I've done the same XD
I wish it wasn't stored this way. Makes it near impossible to do on other devices when you're sharing Zeronet over a network, as any change in domain/IP would reset it again :P
@Spukkin Faceship: Sorry, but I'm going to block your child :P
@Spukkin Faceship: I'm sorry, but it's the only way.
@Spukkin Faceship: I have failed, your son has become too strong for me to block. The apocalypse is nigh.

@ZAlex: Ah, that explains the findUser function I noticed when merging updates into DZM.

PS: It seems that it's case sensitive
What I wonder is, how will people who chose the same name be handled?

And the answer is... it doesn't. Just gives you a blank page if there is more than one person with the same name. Explains why this feature is still hidden. With a hole like that it'd leave it open for people to break other people's profile links.
And now it's broken for me because of the stunt I pulled.

If you click the three-dot menu in the top-right, you can follow your mentions, comments on your posts, and when people follow you. It'll all show up in the ZeroHello newsfeed. Unfortunately there is not yet a way to follow posts you've commented on :P
@Talnicrom: Eww, no. Who wants those filthy casuals lumbering around the place?            /jk

It's basically "Developer mode". It enables extra options that involve signing files and publishing updates. So if you updated a site you're working on, or manually edited your user files for a site like ZeroMe, you can sign those files with your key, authorizing them, and then you can publish your changes to the network. Obviously you can only do this with stuff you made, like comments on a site you posted on, or a blog you're making.
Zeronet or ZeroMe? Zeronet is a distributed web hosting platform where none of the sites are stored on central servers. ZeroMe is a social network that lives on the distributed Zeronet.

Which denpa? There's a lot of things with "denpa" in their title.

Unless you literally mean 電波, then I'd agree that I indeed love them.
@Kaffie: Ah, that makes more sense. Sadly I just can't get into that genre. I don't hate it, and wouldn't mind it being background noise, but I just can't bob to the beat if you know what I mean?
@Kaffie: It's always awesome when you discover a new thing you're into and you can then binge all this stuff you never knew existed before :)
@Kaffie: Don't worry my friend, some of us are sane.

That is a nightmare. I haven't used Dell in ages since they never had the specs I needed in my price range, so I had two HP laptops. First one was a gift, second one I bought myself. Funny enough, both had the same issue of the hinge breaking and the screen starting to fail, despite being completely different models built years apart from each other. It happened to the second one even faster than it did the first. Throwing numerous other small issues I had with both into the mix, and I've sworn off ever buying another HP laptop again.

I'm now using a Lenovo y50-70. I've had zero issues with the hardware besides the slow SSHD that it shipped with, but that has since been replaced by a 1TB SSD. Other than that it's worked great, except for the fact that I'm stuck using Windows on it because of the graphics software I need to use :P  So I haven't tried installing Linux on it myself, but from what I've read of others experience people have gotten distros like Ubuntu working fine.

Protip: For quotes you do this -

```
>This is a quote
```

>This is a quote
Unfortunately it's mostly manual. I use WinMerge to scan for changes every once in a while and then I'll merge what I need.

@ExeciN: That doesn't work very well if you modified code. For example, blindly merging `all.js` or `all.css` with an updated version could cause things to break if you made a decent amount of changes. Writing a script that would be able to account for changes you made would probably involve more work than just skimming through things real quick with WinMerge. 

Of course if the source for whatever you're cloning is available on GitHub(Like all the main Zero* sites are) you could just fork it that way and use git to help you manage merges instead.
That's a bug in Windows Guests. There's a fix for it, but I can't remember off the top of my head. I'll look for it.

Found it: http://www.virtualbox.org/manual/ch12.html#idm10208
This is for slow Folder shares. If you are tying the USB3 drive into the VM then it must be something else. :\
